By ALAN HIRSCH
An overall drop in the
percentage of students accepted,
with specific decreases in the
percentage of women, Blacks,
and Natural Science majors has
been reflected in the admission
statistics.
Thirteen percent frewer than
the number of students who

Science majors were accepted
than last. Fifty percent of the
Natural Science majors who
applied last year were accepted
while this year, only 37 percent
were accepted.
Six hundred and six Natural
Science majors were accepted
this year out of an applicant pool
of 1624, as compared to last
year's figures 786 out of a pool
of 1572.
In addition, the percentage of
pre-med candidates accepted this
year was 11 percent less than last
year. Last year, 1332 students
applied with a pre-med career
goal designated on their
application and 597--44
percent--were accepted. This
year, out of 1476 candidates,
493 pre-meds or 33 percent,
gained acceptance.

accepted this year also dropped
substantially as last year 58

percent of the women applicants
this year gained acceptance.

black applicants to the class of
'78 were accepted, where as last
year, 48 percent of the blacks
were accepted.

increased with respect to Social
and Behavioral Science majors by
about 80 from 389-468, the
number of acceptances stayed
approximately the same at
roughly 290. The decrease in the
percentage of S&BS applicants

2028 male applicants and 959

Leon Madansky one of 342 Guggenheim winners
Hopkins' Physics professor
Leon Madansky has been
awarded one of the 342
fellowhsips annually given to
distinguish ed scholars, scientists.
and artists by the John Simon
Guggenheim Memorial
Foundation.
The pool of grantees for this
year was chosen by the
Guggenheim Committee of
Selection from a field of 2,668
applicants in the Foundation's
fiftienth annual competition.
Madansky will use the grant to
study experimental and
theoretical galactic radio
astronomy.
The fellowships were awarded
on the basis of demonstrated_
accomplishment in the past and
strong promise for future
production. The awards seek to
make possible a year of
continuous study in a field which
the applicant proposes, prior to
the committee's decision.
Recent Guggenheim winners

include critic Gerald Bruns, poet
Jill Hoffman, novelist Tom
Mc Hale, playwrights Mark
Medoff and Susan Yankowitz,
and choreographer Twyla Tharp.
Past grantees of considerable
renown include mathematician
William Browder, chemist Walter
Kauzman:-., critic Richard Poirier,
writer 'Aim Ross, poet Galway
Kinnel, and painter George
Cohen.
The areas of study proposed
by the applicants range through
science, humanities, and the arts.
Howard Gruber will examine the
scientific thought of Jean Piaget,
while Charles Hames will write a
book on techniques of design,
and Gerald Jonas will concern
himself with current neurological
research.
The great majority of
Guggenheim Fellows teach in
American institutions of higher
learning. The University of
California at Berkeley boasts 17
faculty members who have

received Guggenheim grants,
while Columbia University has
15.
The grants are sponsored by an
annual endowment of
S4,151,500 from the
Guggenheim Foundation. During
its 50-year history the
Foundation has granted nearly
8,500 fellowships for an amount
of money in excess of $55
million.

for this year's awards includes
Mark Kac, professor of
mathematics at Rockefeller
University, ARthur Kornberg,

Stanford University, Willard F.
Libby, professor of chemistry at
the University of California, and

for Mount Washington as the

Friday night.

evening with nine point on four
tallies and five feeds. Even so, the
